Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: Design documents are due soon and other teams are waiting for their technical input
Story:
I stared at my phone, my mother’s message glowing on the screen: “We need you to lead the ceremony this year. It means a lot to your father.” My heart thudded. This ceremony was more than a ritual—it was a thread tying our family together, a tradition my parents cherished. I knew how much it would mean to them if I stepped up, especially now, when everyone looked to me to carry the torch.

But my laptop chimed with Slack notifications. The product manager was asking for my feedback on the new feature specs. The design document deadline was tomorrow, and the other teams were waiting for my technical input to move forward. I could almost feel their impatience through the screen; any delay from me would hold up the whole project.

I felt pulled in two directions, the weight of my family’s expectations pressing on one side, the responsibility to my team on the other. My mind raced, guilt and anxiety tangling together. I wanted to be the son my parents needed, but I also didn’t want to let my colleagues down. I sat there, torn, unsure which role I could afford to disappoint.
